Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) is a degree-completion pathway for graduates of an Ontario college advanced diploma program in Building Renovation Technology. Students must complete Years 3 and 4 to obtain their bachelor's degree in Construction Management.

The curriculum combines theory, applied research, field study, and hands-on practical education in construction engineering and technology with studies in business and management methods as applied to construction. Graduates are entitled to the academic credential designation of Hons. B.Tech. (Construction Management).

The program is accredited by the Canadian Institute of Quantity Surveyors (CIQS) and graduates qualify for Gold Seal Certification (GSC) offered by the Canadian Construction Association (CCA).

The mandatory field experience semester, offered in the spring/summer of the third year, requires a minimum of 450 hours of appropriate field experience or equivalent. Students can complete this requirement through the Field Experience course or Prior Learning Assessment Recognition (PLAR) if they have prior relevant experience.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T316 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program at the college prepares graduates for careers in various roles within the construction industry, including but not limited to: construction manager, project manager, project coordinator, field engineer, site superintendent, estimator, project monitor, building science specialist, building condition assessor, construction sales manager, construction claims specialist, construction quality control specialist, construction health and safety specialist, construction cost consultant, developer, project controls specialist, site inspector, contractor, and subcontractor.

Graduates of this program can seek to complete the Field Experience requirement through the PLAR process if they have prior field experience equivalent to the minimum requirement. The industry requires construction managers with specialized skills to effectively function within multidisciplinary teams and possess a broad technical and business management background. Construction managers plan, organize, lead, and control construction projects from start to finish while adhering to design, regulatory compliance requirements, contracts, specifications, budgets, schedules, and sustainable construction techniques and practices.

The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program is fully accredited by the Canadian Institute of Quantity Surveyors (CIQS), the Chartered Institute of Building (CIOB), and the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS). Graduates are qualified to obtain professional memberships in various construction management associations, such as CIQS, where they can obtain the Professional Quantity Surveyors (PQS) or Construction Estimator Certified (CEC) designation.

There is no explicit mention of years, numbers, emails, or names in the text.

Context: The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree is offered at George Brown College. Graduates can obtain the Gold Seal Certification (GSC) in the Canadian construction industry for superintendents, foremen, estimators, project managers, owner’s construction managers and safety practitioners. Industry leaders such as Temple Harris, vice-chairman of Gillam Group; Christopher Rick from PCL Constructors, Canada Inc.; James Zippel, general manager of Electrical Service & Projects at Ainsworth; Greg Kozicz, president of Alberici Constructors, Ltd.; and Michael George, president of Trisura Insurance, have expressed the importance of proper training and education in the construction sector. The program is designed to meet the requirement for construction professionals and strengthen the long-term success of the industry. The Gold Seel Certification is based on the candidate’s education, training, and professional work experience.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T316 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) program graduates qualify for graduate studies in relevant fields. Some graduates have pursued further studies at universities like the University of Waterloo, Columbia University, and Toronto Metropolitan University.

Required courses in semester 4 include Construction Materials, Construction Materials Testing and Analysis, Construction Estimating 1, Construction Estimating 2 – Pricing, Commercial Construction Technology, Mechanical and Electrical Construction Practices, and two Liberal Studies electives.

Semester 5 courses include Soils and Foundations, Highrise Construction Technology, Construction Estimating 3 – Bidding, Construction Health and Safety, Construction Site Engineering, Heavy Construction 1, Work Term Preparation 1, Applications in Building Science, Capstone 1 – Bid Competition, Work Term Preparation 2, Heavy Construction Management Practices 2, Construction Contract Administration, Construction Quality Practices, and two Liberal Studies electives.

The program includes a summer field experience (Work Term) of 450 hours in semester 7.

Additionally, courses like Economics of Project Development and Preconstruction Cost Planning are offered in semester 7.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) Program (Bridging) T316 | George Brown College2023.txt

The text provides information about the course offerings and learning outcomes for a degree completion pathway in Construction Management at George Brown College. Here are the factual information and entities extracted from the text:

* Courses: "Economics of Project Development", "Preconstruction Cost Planning", "Applications in Building Information Modelling (BIM)", "Decision Analysis and Critical Thinking", "Research Methods", "Construction Project Procurement 1", "Labour Relations and Human Resources Management", "Construction Risk Management", "Sustainable Construction", "Capstone 2 – Industry Research", "Project Financial Monitoring", "Construction Project Procurement 2", "Leadership and Ethics for Construction Managers"

* Program learning outcomes: Use relevant media to communicate all manner of information related to a construction project, Analyze the past performance of construction projects to predict and improve the execution of future projects, Manage construction projects in a compliant, safe, ethical and sustainable manner, Apply management tools and techniques to execute construction projects on time and within budget, Recognize and value the diversity of opinions, processes and approaches in executing construction projects, Incorporate effective leadership strategies to develop high-functioning, multidisciplinary and multicultural teams and work groups, Apply the principles and practices of leadership development and human resources to manage and develop people in the construction industry, Analyze technical problems encountered in construction projects and develop appropriate solutions in accordance with the principles and practices of construction science and management, Apply business, accounting and financial principles and practices to effectively manage construction project costs, Apply the principles and practices of construction management in assessing the key performance indicators of construction projects
